Luca_PI wrote:

>Hi,
>i want to post a little idea. First of all sorry for my english, and 
>i'm a beginner in AI so this would be a stupid idea. :)
>Our brain grow in the first 3 years and after begin to decrease 
>eliminating everything (connections and neurons) which are not used, 
>isn't true?
>  
>
Not quite correct. It used to be believed that all of the *neurons* were 
formed in the first few years, and you would then loose neurons for the 
rest of your life. I think that recent research has shown that new 
neurons are formed in certain areas of the brain (hippocampus I think) 
and can migrate to other nearby areas.

Connections though are being created and lost all througout your life, 
that is most likely how long term memory and new skills get encoded. I 
think it would be fair to say that the bulk of neurons and connections 
are grown in the first few years of life though.

>so if I understand NEAT it's evolve considering also a smallest 
>structure if it fitness than the other...
>  
>
Speciation allows us to evolve simple and complex networks together, 
yes. I think that is what you are asking :)

>but when we reach the task we could have a great topology...
>  
>
>should be or not usefull implements a way in which the program try 
>only to eliminate part of the structure?
>it will be a "NEAT reverse" trying to preserve the fitness...
>  
>
When we find a good network it might be very large, some of that 
structure may be redundant, it might be a good idea to trim away some of 
that excess structure.

This has been discussed on the list recently, check the 'Bloat' thread. 
We use the word Bloat to describe this excess structure. I have plans to 
build structure trimming into SharpNEAT .

Also Derek and Philip wrote a paper about using deletion mutations 
within NEAT. Using deletion mutations helps to keep structures trimmed. 
The paper is in the FILES section of this group, the file is 
modular-neat.ps.gz

Derek, Philip, hope the presentation went well.

Colin.
